Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of an E-Beam Evaporator for Interdisciplinary Research and Education

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
The objective of this program is to strengthen the fabrication capabilities at Wake Forest University (WFU) by acquisition of an electron-beam evaporation system. This instrument will be unique in northwest North Carolina, provide a comprehensive fabrication-characterization infrastructure, and allow investigators to improve the quality and expand the scope of their research and training endeavors.

Intellectual merit: The system will enable researchers to grow single and multilayered non-magnetic, ferromagnetic and organic metals, (doped metal) oxides, nitrides and a wide range of semiconductors. It will advance several nanoscience, nanotechnology, biotechnology and energy programs with the potential to yield transformative applications in organic electronics and spintronics, solid oxide fuel cells, solid electrolytes for Li-ion batteries, high-performance scintillators for homeland security, photocatalytic membranes for water splitting and CO2 reduction, and the study of cell mechanics and protein mobility during neoplastic transformation. Crucial fabrication tasks to realize these advances are limited or impossible due to the current lack of infrastructure.

Broader impacts: The instrument will significantly enhance multidisciplinary cross-departmental research collaborations among groups from WFU, neighboring institutions and small companies. Over 50 students and postdoctoral fellows from WFU, Appalachian State University, Winston-Salem State University, and Forsyth Technical Community College will use this instrument for over 15 research projects. The system will support curricular improvement by allowing new experiments that will expand Physics and Chemistry syllabi. About 150 graduate and undergraduate students will receive formal training in the 7 courses and a summer workshop that will use the instrument.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Wake Forest University (WFU) integrates opportunities to perform state-of-the-art research with its strong liberal arts undergraduate education and individually intensive graduate training. It is the only institution in western North Carolina offering PhD degrees in Chemistry and Physics. Its research scope and infrastructure have expanded considerably with funding secured by its faculty. While we already had state-of-the-art instrumentation for structural, electronic, and optical characterization, the new instrument for e-beam/thermal evaporation fulfilled our critical needs in fabrication, allowing us to pursue exciting cutting edge projects otherwise not possible, to improve the quality and expand the scope of our research. The instrument has quickly became a key component of our fabrication efforts, catalyzing new multidisciplinary research collaborations and strengthening our program. Its presence on campus has had and continues to have tremendous impact on the quality of several programs focusing on nanoscience, nanotechnology, biotechnology and energy research. Several projects rely on the functions of this instrument and will otherwise have to use similar equipment 100 mi away, slowing and limiting progress. The instrument generates considerable interest in the following areas: organic electronics and spintronics, development of materials for solid oxide fuel cells, study of solid electrolytes for Li-ion batteries, high-performance scintillators, study of cell mechanics and protein mobility during neoplastic transformation. The system has 15 certified users at the moment, after only 6 months from its installation, and it is expected that over 50 undergraduate, graduate students and postdoctoral fellows from WFU, Appalachian State University (ASU), Winston-Salem State University (HBCU), and Forsyth Technical Community College will adopt this instrument in the future for more than 15 different research projects.

 

The impact of the new instrument on our training infrastructure is broad, allowing us to strengthen existing education and outreach activities, and to initiate new ones that would otherwise be impossible. The PI, co-PIs and senior personnel have a successful history of mentoring undergraduate and graduate students in research and they will build on this track record to mentor more students from WFU and ASU and also to reach out to other institutions where research experiences for students are limited. The instrument is also supporting curricular improvement by allowing new experiments that will expand Physics and Chemistry syllabi at WFU. Beyond the academic community, the PI and co-PIs are engaged in many outreach activities that benefit from this instrument, and they are already using it as a recruitment tool for new students, as well as for tours given to high-school students.
